results.title: Fishing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Illustrates the fishing methods of some Australian First Nations people, shown fishing on a lake using three-pronged spears from bark canoes. With Bill Onus.

results.title: Emu hunt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Hunting for the emu. Two men after finding eggs follow the spoor across the desert, with their spears held ready to catch their prey.

results.title: Boomerang
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Demonstrates how a boomerang is made. The diligent search for the exact right piece of wood, the burning off of the outer bark, the laborious whittling with a sharpened stone and the fashioning of the slight twist at each end to achieve its unique quality of returning to its point of departure. Introduced by Bill Onus.

results.title: Bark canoe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Shows the methods of canoe manufacture employed by some Australian First Nations peoples. Illustrates the removal of bark from a tree in a single section, its shaping and testing, and finally the canoe’s use for fishing. Introduced by Bill Onus.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: art, life and religion
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Modern social studies”.
A portrayal of some aspects of Australian First Nations people’s ceremonial practices. The spiritual significance of body paintings, dancing and singing is explained. Taken during the University of Sydney’s expedition to Arnhem Land, led by Professor A. P. Elkin in 1952.

results.title: Gurrawilla
results.creator_credit: Ross Campbell, Chelsea Studios for the Education Department of Victoria and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alan Marshall: author and man”.
At one time, Marshall lived with First Nations people in Arnhem Land, and he tells us how he became known as ‘Gurrawilla’. He also describes in a light-hearted manner tales of his childhood.

results.title: Aborigines in the Alice
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Looks at two problems facing First Nations people in Alice Springs - child care and alcoholism. In 1970 the death rate among First Nations children rose to nearly 1 in 5, one of the highest infant mortality rates in the world. Today the ratio has improved, but the health of First Nations people still presents a grim picture. Interviews people concerned. Reporter: Brian King; Photographer: Richard Bailie-Mace; Sound: Peter Lipscomb.

results.title: Bad Street Brawler for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, manual and blurb card in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Bad Street Brawler, the player plays the character Duke Davis, a former punk rocker and the “world’s coolest” martial artist. Duke has to work his way through each level beating up the crooks that get in his way. Before the start of the next stage, quotes are introduced to entertain the player, such as “Never trouble trouble until trouble troubles you”. The player’s moves are limited to kicks and punches but new moves and attacks become available as the game progresses, along with new enemy types such as gorillas flinging bananas, menacing stakeboarders and circus strongmen. Bad Street Brawler is one of two games designed specifically for Mattel’s Power Glove.

results.title: Blackmagic Design Media Preservation Lab
results.brief_description: The Media Preservation Lab is a purposed built public facing lab.
results.description: There are about 250,000 artefacts in the ACMI Collection. We’ve been collecting film, videogames, artworks, home movies, stills and press kits – as well as a huge range of other paraphernalia – for over 75 years, ever since ACMI was conceived as a film lending and education organisation known as the State Film Centre. Inside the Blackmagic Media Preservation Lab, our staff and collaborators are digitising our film and time-based media collections, assessing physical artefacts from our videogame collection and film donations, as well as conducting hours of quality assessment work on our born-digital works to make the collection accessible onsite and online.
description_for_label: There are about 250,000 artefacts in the ACMI Collection, which we’ve been collecting for over 75 years – ever since ACMI was conceived as a film lending and education organisation called the State Film Centre. In the Blackmagic Media Preservation Lab, we’re digitising our film and time-based media collections, assessing physical artefacts from our videogame collection and film donations, as well as making the collection accessible onsite and online.
